Moishe -- sorry about that.  The earliest Langsam that I know of would be 
my grandfather's father, whose name was Shuel, or Shoel. My father was 
named after him and my father's Hebrew name is pronounced (as he was 
called and pronounces it, I suppose it's the Yiddish form) Shoel.  My 
grandfather was born in 1890, in a village near Vienna in what was then 
part of  Austro-Hungary.  He came to this country in 1906 and settled in 
the St. Louis area.

Take care,

Barbara

Dear Moishe,

Yes, my brother's name is David and he was named for my grandfather (I 
should have included his name before). And yes, my mother's name is 
Esther. 

And yes, Harry Langsam was my grandfather's older brother. And yes, his 
offspring are our cousins and we know them well.  My grandfather had 
another brother, Morris, who married Rose (I think maiden name Fish). 
She was my grandmother's aunt. My grandmother was Flora Fish, and I think 
her mother's maiden name was Spira, which I see is a family name of other 
Langsam relatives. I know that my grandparents came from the same area in 
Europe.

How did Pesach Langsam take the surname "Langsam"?  You know that it is 
German for "slowly". Was your direct ancestor a Miller by profession? I know 
that that's how many surnames were adopted then.

Best,

Barbara

Barbara Langsam Shuman, LA 75, 
          is in the second year of her term as president of the board of directors 
          of the St. Louis Jewish Light newspaper. She was associate editor 
          of the weekly paper in the mid-1980s and is the first former staff member 
          to serve as president of the newspaper's board. She is senior account 
          manager with Finkel & Co. Communications, a St. Louis-based marketing 
          communications firm, where she has worked since 1992. Her husband, Michael 
          A. Shuman, LW 82 ("No, I didn't really rob the cradle—he 
          enrolled in law school after earning two graduate degrees!"), is 
          associate county counselor for St. Louis County. Daughter Amanda, 12, 
          was awarded a red ribbon for her science project in the Greater St.
